title: Retract (group theory)
summary: In mathematics, in the field of group theory, a subgroup of a group is termed a retract if there is an endomorphism of the group that maps surjectively to the subgroup and is identity on the subgroup. In symbols, H {\displaystyle H} is a retract of G {\displaystyle G} if and only if there is an endomorphism σ : G → G {\displaystyle \sigma :G\to G} such that σ ( h ) = h {\displaystyle \sigma (h)=h} for all h ∈ H {\displaystyle h\in H} and σ ( g ) ∈ H {\displaystyle \sigma (g)\in H} for all g ∈ G {\displaystyle g\in G} .[1][2]
